abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: Hybridization and polyploidy are major drivers of plant diversification, often leading to novel ecological traits through changes in gene regulation. Among these, small RNAs (smRNAs) play a key role, particularly through their interactions with transposable elements (TEs). Using a common garden setup, we comparatively investigated how smRNAs, including those targeting TEs, contribute to post-allopolyploid genome stabilization and ecological divergence in two sibling allotetraploid marsh orchids (Dactylorhiza majalis and D. traunsteineri) and their diploid progenitors. Despite independent origins, both allopolyploids exhibited substantial overlap in smRNA targeting, including transgressive overexpression around genes linked to stress response, cell division and transcriptional regulation. TE-targeting 24 nt smRNAs followed patterns consistent with subgenome size and origin, while shorter 20–23 nt smRNAs displayed greater divergence. The older allotetraploid D. majalis exhibited enhanced smRNA-mediated fine-tuning of gene copy number regulation, while its younger sibling D. traunsteineri showed more pronounced non-additive expression patterns, suggesting ongoing resolution of post-polyploid meiotic and mitotic instability. These findings reveal a two-phase smRNA response to allopolyploidy: early genome stabilization followed by regulatory fine-tuning. Our study highlights the central role of smRNAs in resolving genomic conflict, enabling functional divergence, and driving ecological innovation during polyploid evolution.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Allopolyploidization—the combination of whole-genome duplication (WGD) and interspecific hybridization—is a potent evolutionary force, generating genetic diversity, gene redundancy, and buffering capacity that underpin evolutionary innovation and ecological diversification. However, the initial merger of divergent genomes into a single nucleus frequently destabilizes genome regulation (i.e., triggering “genomic shock”, McClintock 1984), often on the background of a severe genetic bottleneck.

Small noncoding RNAs (smRNAs) have emerged as key mediators during post-polyploidization genome stabilization (e.g., Ha et al. 2009; Shen et al. 2017; Cavé-Radet et al. 2020). These short RNA molecules supress transposable elements (TEs) and fine-tune gene expression, promoting both genome integrity and adaptive responses. Specifically, repeat-associated or heterochromatic small-interfering RNAs (ra-siRNAs/het-siRNAs; Shen et al. 2017) help maintain chromatin stability, while microRNAs (miRNAs) can modulate gene expression with phenotypic implications (Ha et al. 2009; Ghani et al. 2014; Jiang et al. 2021). In addition, plant smRNAs orchestrate abiotic and biotic stress responses (Kaur et al. 2021; Tiwari and Rajam 2022; Zhan and Meyers 2024), potentially facilitating adaptation to novel, non-parental environments. These dual roles make smRNAs integral to allopolyploid success.

In general, smRNAs operate through three main mechanisms: (1) post-transcriptional gene silencing (PTGS), binding to RNAs to repress translation or promote cleavage and degradation; (2) transcriptional gene silencing (TGS), directing epigenetic silencing at homologous genomic loci; and (3) splicing regulation, interacting with pre-mRNAs to influence splice-site selection (Borges and Martienssen 2015; Wang and Chekanova 2016). In plants, smRNAs are classified by biogenesis into miRNAs (20–22 nt long, hairpin-derived), and small-interfering RNAs (siRNAs, from double stranded RNA) (Borges and Martienssen 2015; Chen and Rechavi 2021), with siRNAs further divided into: (i) ra-siRNAs (24 nt and primarily involved in TGS), (ii) secondary siRNAs (~21–22nt long, which can function in both TGS and PTGS pathways), and (iii) natural antisense transcript siRNA (nat-siRNA, 21–24 nt, acting both in cis and trans via PTGS) (Borges and Martienssen 2015; Chen and Rechavi 2021).

Recent reviews (e.g., Ariel and Manavella 2021; Tossolini et al. 2025) highlight the pivotal link between TE mobilization and smRNA evolution. TEs not only contribute regulatory capacity through enhancer-derived transcripts (e.g., in wheat; TE-initiated enhancer-like elements, Xie et al. 2023), but also spur the emergence of smRNAs and long non-coding RNAs that diversify gene regulation and support genome plasticity (Hassan et al. 2024; Tossolini et al. 2025).

WGD, similarly to environmental stress, is known to lead to TE activation, resulting in accumulation of repeat-derived smRNAs, boosting both TGS and PTGS pathways (Ito et al. 2011; Kenan-Eichler et al. 2011; Marí-Ordóñez et al. 2013; Fultz et al. 2015; Xiao and Wang 2025). For example, resynthesized Arabidopsis allotetraploids rapidly restore ra-siRNA populations after WGD, while miRNAs show non-additive expression patterns and play key roles in stabilizing hybrid genomes (Ha et al. 2009). Similarly, early generations Brassica napus allotetraploids exhibit a surge in TE-derived 21 nt siRNAs, especially from Gypsy elements, helping to silence newly active TEs (Martinez Palacios et al. 2019). Cavé-Radet et al. (2020, 2023) observed stronger miRNA responses in allopolyploid Spartina compared to homoploid hybrids, suggesting a more pronounced regulatory impact of WGD than hybridization alone (Cavé-Radet et al. 2020). On the other hand, the divergence between progenitors determines the extent of genomic shock in wheat allotetraploids, with enhanced smRNA responses associated with TEs in hybrid crosses between parents with differing TE load, compared to those with similar TE content (Jiao et al. 2018).

Despite growing interest in the role of smRNAs in allopolyploid evolution, most research has focused on early-generation or synthetic polyploids. To our knowledge, only Cavé-Radet et al. (2020) have examined smRNAs in wild allopolyploids, albeit also in early stages (Spartina F1 hybrids and S. anglica, ~170 years old). Thus, the long-term dynamics, regulatory roles and potential ecological relevance of smRNAs in more established allopolyploid lineages remain poorly explored.

In this study, we focus on two ecologically-distinct, well-established, sibling orchid allotetraploids, Dactylorhiza majalis s.str. and D. traunsteineri, to address the long-term fate of smRNAs following allopolyploidization. The marsh orchids within D. majalis s.l. includes several independently formed sibling allotetraploids, each likely with multiple origins involving overlapping stocks of parental populations (Brandrud et al. 2020). The focal allotetraploids here share a complex history of repeated polyploidization and/or hybridization and back-crossing, but are today reasonably well separated in morphology and habitat preferences (Fig. 1a; Wolfe et al. 2023). They are estimated to have formed approximately 104k (D. majalis) and 74k (D. traunsteineri) generations ago (Hawranek 2021), from the diploid progenitors D. fuchsii (maternal, smaller genome) and D. incarnata (paternal, larger genome) (Fig. 1a) (Aagard et al. 2005; Brandrud et al. 2020; Eriksson et al. 2022). Transcriptomic comparisons of the diploids have revealed large-scale gene expression differences, importantly, including differences in smRNA-mediated regulation of TEs and PTGS-related pathways (Balao et al. 2017). Further, Eriksson et al. (2022) reported significant differences in both genome size and TE load between the two diploid progenitors.
In short, D. traunsteneri prefers marshes and fens with high, whereas D. majalis s.str. (hereafter D. majalis) grows in mesic to moist meadows.

Distinct ecological, spatial, morphological and physiological properties have been reported for the two sibling allopolyploids (Paun et al. 2010, 2011; Balao et al. 2016; Wolfe et al. 2023). D. majalis is distributed across continental Europe, ranging from the Pyrenees to Scandinavia, with a broader ecological niche (i.e., mesic to moist meadows) and less geographically-driven genetic differentiation than D. traunsteineri which is found in disjunct marshes and fens in the Alps, Scandinavia and British Isles. Wolfe and colleagues (2023) reported physiological differences in photosynthesis and nutrient transport consistent with the contrasting ecological conditions preferred by the two allotetraploids. These appear to have helped the two allotetraploids adapt to different soil chemistry conditions, with D. traunsteineri restricted to wet, nutrient-poor soils, in particular with extremely low levels of nitrate (Wolfe et al. 2023). Furthermore, reciprocal transplant experiments have shown that much of the gene expression divergence between the sibling allopolyploids is enviromentally plastic, and appeared to be associated to distinct, environmentally-driven, biotic communities in their roots (Emelianova et al. 2025). In stark contrast, analysis of the genomes of several Dactylorhiza allopolyploids found relatively little difference between D. majalis and D. traunsteineri both in genome size and TE activity suggesting a strong control of TEs following recurrent allopolyploidizations (Eriksson et al. 2022).

In this study, we comparatively investigate the extent of smRNAs regulation in D. majalis and D. traunsteineri. Specifically, we study: (1) how does smRNA abundance in the allopolyploids reflects parental expression—whether it follows additive, dominant, or transgressive patterns—and how consistent are these patterns across the sibling allopolyploids; (2) the degree and similarity of smRNA targeting of TEs in the two sibling allotetraploids; (3) potential correlations between smRNA-mediated gene regulation and distinct eco-physiological traits of D. majalis and D. traunsteineri.

sec.title: Sampling
sec.p: Adult specimens of each species of interest were transplanted from multiple localities across Europe to a common garden in Vienna, Austria. Dactylorhiza includes perennial plants that produce a new tuber yearly, which supports growth in the following year. Two years after transplantation, in the morning of 14 May 2014, leaf tissue at a similar developmental stage for all accessions was fixed in RNAlater (Sigma) and stored at -80°C until further processing. Our final sampling included four accessions of each diploid (D. incarnata and D. fuchsii), together with nine (D. majalis) and twelve (D. traunsteineri) individuals of each allotetraploid (Supplementary Table S1). With few exceptions, each accession of each species originated from different localities across Europe. The diploid smRNA data has been previously investigated by Balao et al. (2017). Independent RNA isolations from the same tissue fixations of D. majalis and D. traunsteineri were used for RNA-seq analyses by Wolfe et al. (2023).

sec.title: Library preparations and sequencing
sec.p: Small RNA extraction, library preparation and sequencing for this experiment was previously described for diploid investigations (Balao et al. 2017). In short, isolation of smRNA was performed with the mirVana miRNA Isolation Kit (Life Technologies). The smRNA-enriched RNA extracts were further purified by gel size selection on 15% TBE-Urea pre-casted gels (Life Technologies). The small RNA libraries were prepared with the NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina (New England Biolabs). Illumina sequencing as 50 bp single-end reads was performed at the Vienna BioCenter Core Facilities (VBCF; https://www.viennabiocenter.org/).

sec.title: Read processing and quantifying
sec.p: The libraries were demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder v.1.03 (available from http://wtsi-npg.github.io/illumina2bam/#BamIndexDecoder). The raw reads were quality filtered, trimmed from adapters used by the NEB kit, and size selected for the range 20-24 nt using the CLC Genomics Workbench v.8.0 (QIAGEN). The filtered reads were mapped to the available reference genome of D. incarnata v.1.0 (Wolfe et al. 2023) using STAR v.2.7.3a (Dobin et al. 2013), with the settings --alignIntronMax 1 and --outFilterMismatchNoverLmax 0.05. A single pass alignment approach was used, retaining further only multi-mapping reads under a threshold of 100 (--outFilterMulitmapNmax 100). A structural annotation-free approach was used for the initial analysis, in order to identify any regions of the genome (including non-genic) being differentially targeted (DT) by smRNA. After sorting the bam files by reference coordinates with Samtools v.1.10 (Danacek et al. 2011), read coverage was assessed for each individual along 100 bp windows of the genome using bamCoverage from deepTools2 v.3.5.1 (Ramirez et al. 2016). All windows with a minimum coverage of ten in at least one sample were retained in a bed file; neighbouring windows were merged into continuous regions using bedtools merge v.2.29.2 (Quinlan and Hall 2010). The bed file containing retained regions (i.e., peaks of smRNA targeting) across all individuals was then converted into a gff3 file with a custom python script. Lastly, a table of counts was obtained running featureCounts from the Subread v.2.0.0 package (Liao et al. 2014), accounting for multiple mappers fractionally (-M --fraction), taking into account the possibility of smRNA targeting in trans. The pipeline, scripts and raw count file, together with the peak gff3 file are available at https://github.com/mc-er/dact-sRNAs.

sec.title: Differential smRNA targeting analysis
sec.p: Differently targeted regions were identified using R v.4.1.1 and the Bioconductor package EdgeR v.3.34.0 (Robinson et al. 2010; McCarthy et al. 2012). The count matrix was filtered to retain genomic regions with a minimum smRNA mapping of one count per million (CPM) for a minimum of 25% of the number of samples in a group and a minimum of two samples. To account for differences in library sizes the data was normalised using the weighted trimmed mean of M-values (TMM) method. A quasi-likelihood negative binomial model was implemented to find differentially targeted regions across the genome comparing either the two sibling allotetraploids or an allotetraploid towards either parental diploid. P-values were corrected for multiple testing using the Benjamini–Hochberg (BH) procedure and genomic regions only passing an FDR value of 0.05 were kept for further reporting.

Analyses targeting genomic regions around TEs were performed for reads with lengths 20–23 nt, and separately for 24 nt reads (i.e., potentially heterochromatic smRNAs, hetsiRNAs, Borges and Martienssen 2015). For analyses of genic regions all read lengths were grouped together (20–24 nt) in one analysis per comparison.

sec.title: Assessing genomic interactions
sec.p: Differentially targeted peaks passing a multiple testing-corrected significance threshold of 0.05 were classified as three categories of genomic interactions (Supplementary Table S2): (1) additivity—the polyploid was down regulated towards one diploid and up regulated against the other, (2) transgressive—the polyploid was up/down regulated towards both diploids, and (3) dominance—the polyploid showed no significant difference towards one diploid (the dominant) and was up/down regulated compared to the other diploid. We tested deviation from the stochastically expected number of shared peaks between the two tetraploids in each category using a hypergeometric test implemented in the Bioconductor package SuperExactTest (Wang et al. 2015).

sec.title: Functional interpretation of DT genes
sec.p: To get insights into a putative role for smRNA targeting in defining the divergent ecological properties between the sibling allopolyploids a gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis of DT genes was conducted. Since the molecular effects of smRNA targeting are expected to be different depending on the respective type of targeted region, we analysed genic regions targeted by smRNAs around promoters separately from those targeted in exons or introns. Genes targeted around promoters would be expected to be down regulated or silenced, whereas those targeted by smRNAs in the gene body could experience a post-transcriptional effect or alternative splicing. Enrichment analyses for genic regions potentially affected by DT peaks were performed in R v.4.1.1, using the Bioconductor package topGO v.2.44.0 (Alexa and Rahnenfuhre 2021). We used Fisher’s exact test statistics with the “weight01” algorithm to test for over-representation of specific functions. An FDR correction of p-values to account for multiple testing was applied and significance was set to a threshold of 0.05.

sec.title: smRNAs and their genomic targets
sec.p: Sequencing produced an average 13.5 M reads per accession (±5.9 M SD). After quality filtering and size selection, we retained an average of 5.8 M reads (±3.2 M SD) of 20–24 nt (Supplementary Table S3). On average, 83.1% (±4.2%SD) of the 20–24 nt reads were successfully mapped to the D. incarnata reference genome, with no observed mapping bias across the different species (Supplementary Table S3). The distribution of read lengths matched the expected profile for smRNAs (Borges and Martienssen 2015), showing modes at 21–22 nt and 24 nt across all species (Fig. 2a).

In general, D. fuchsii exhibited higher CPM amounts of 20–22 nt smRNAs compared to D. incarnata, although only the 21 nt smRNAs were significantly different between the two diploids (Fig 2a–c). The reverse trend was observed for the 23–24 nt smRNAs, with D. incarnata showing significantly higher CPM values for both 23 nt and 24 nt smRNAs compared to D. fuchsii (Fig. 2a). The two allotetraploids were much more similar to each other than the diploid species (Fig. 2a). For the 21 nt smRNAs, both allotetraploids had a significantly higher CPM than their paternal species (D. incarnata), but significantly lower CPM than the maternal species (D. fuchsii) (Fig. 2a). A large proportion of the 20–22 nt smRNAs mapped to exonic regions, while 24 nt smRNAs mapped predominantly to TEs and intergenic regions (Fig. 2b–c, Supplementary Fig. S1).

Our annotation-free approach identified 2,454,439 putative smRNA targeting peaks across the reference genome. After filtering to retain peaks with CPM > 1 in at least two samples and 25% of samples within a group, between 102,222 and 370,440 peaks were retained depending on the comparison. A multidimensional scaling (MDS) plot based on all 20–24 nt smRNAs reads across 212,434 peaks clearly separated the two diploid species (D. fuchsii and D. incarnata), as well as the diploids from the allotetraploids, while the allotetraploids overlapped centrally (Fig. 1b). Within D. traunsteineri a geographical clustering was apparent (not shown).

sec.title: smRNA activity in ecologically-divergent allopolyploids
sec.p: We first compared the two ecologically divergent sibling allotetraploids using the combined set of 20–24 nt reads, retaining 152,503 peaks that passed the CPM filtering threshold (Supplementary Table S4). Among these, we identified 2,106 DT peaks between D. traunsteineri and D. majalis, of which approximately half (1,016 peaks) were associated with genes. Gene-associated peaks were defined as those overlapping a gene model (including exons and introns) or within 1,000 bp upstream of a gene model (hereafter referred to as ‘promoters’) (Supplementary Table S4).

The majority of genic DT smRNA peaks (i.e., 762) were located within introns. A smaller number (82) overlapped multiple genic features (intron, exon, and/or promoters) (Supplementary Table S4). Across all genic categories, at least three times more smRNA peaks were over-targeted in the older allotetraploid D. majalis compared to D. traunsteineri (Supplementary Table S4, Fig. 3a–c).

Comparison of DT peaks with previously identified differentially expressed (DE) genes from the same experiment (Wolfe et al. 2023) revealed that most genes DT by smRNAs did not show differential expression between the two allopolyploids. This suggests that smRNAs may be involved in post-transcritional regulation or alternative splicing, rather than transcriptional silencing or activation (Fig. 3f, Supplementary Table S5).

GO enrichment analysis of genes DT by smRNAs between the ecologically divergent allotetraploids revealed an asymmetric overrepresentation of functional categories, with more GO terms enriched among genes more highly targeted in D. majalis than in D. traunsteineri (Fig. 5a, Supplementary Tables S6–S7). The vast majority of enriched terms were found among genes targeted within gene bodies, and were associated with functions related to regulation of transcription and translation, transmembrane transport, response to biotic and abiotic stress, DNA repair, and regulation of meiosis and/or mitosis (Supplementary Table S7).

sec.title: smRNA targeting and genomic interactions
sec.p: We further compared the 20-24 nt smRNA targeting patterns of each sibling allotetraploid to those of the parental diploid species. After filtering, 212,434 peaks were retained for this analysis (Supplementary Table S4). Overall, both allotetraploids showed similar targeting patterns when compared to the diploids, although the younger D. traunsteineri displayed a more divergent smRNA landscape than D. majalis (Supplementary Table S4, Supplementary Fig. S2). In both cases, the allotetraploids also showed greater divergence from the maternal parent (D. fuchsii) than from the paternal D. incarnata (Supplementary Table S4, Supplementary Fig. S2).

We characterised DT smRNAs peaks into four interaction types: additive, transgressive, and dominant towards either diploid parent. The majority of peaks showed no change between the allotetraploids and either diploid. Among those with DT, non-additive patterns were most frequent, with dominance being the most common, particularly towards D. incarnata (Supplementary Table S8, Fig. 4a–f, Supplementary Fig. S3–S4). Notably, in intergenic regions lacking annotated TEs, we observed a higher proportion of smRNA peaks showing dominance towards D. fuchsii than observed for any other genomic contexts (Supplementary Table S8, Fig 4d, Supplementary Fig. S3). Among the transgressive peaks, both allotetraploids most frequently showed over-targeting by smRNAs in comparison to both diploid parents (Supplementary Table S8, Fig. 4a, Fig. 4c–f, Supplementary Fig. S3–S4). A notable general pattern over all types of genomic interactions was that a large proportion of DT smRNA peaks were shared between the two sibling allotetraploids (Supplementary Table S8, Fig. 4b–c, Supplementary Fig. S3–S4), despite their independent evolutionary histories (Brandrud et al. 2020; Hawranek 2021).

We also examined the distribution of interaction categories across genic regions (promoters, exons, introns). In D. majalis, nerly 75% promoter-associated DT peaks showed dominance towards D. incarnata, and almost 50% showed lower smRNA targeting than D. fuchsii (Supplementary Fig. S5). In contrast, D. traunsteineri exhibited greater dominance toward D. fuchsii across all genic regions compared to D. majalis (Supplementary Fig. S5).

For genes transgressively targeted by smRNAs, similar functional categories were enriched in both allotetraploids, including response to stress, transport, regulation of transcription/translation, and regulation of meiosis/mitosis. However, these enrichments involved largely different genes and pathways in each species (Fig. 5b–c, Supplementary Tables S9–S12). In D. traunsteineri, transgressive smRNA targeting was associated with enrichment for cell cycle regulation and stress response functions, and the respective genes were targeted within exons or introns (Fig. 5b, Supplementary Tables S11–S12). In D. majalis, transgressive peaks occurred mostly within introns, and enrichments were associated with regulation of gene function (Fig. 5c, Supplementary Tables S9–S10).

sec.title: smRNAs targeting TEs
sec.p: For the TE-focused analyses, we divided the data into two sets: (a) 24 nt smRNAs, analysed separately since they should be predominantly het-siRNAs and therefore target more frequently TEs (Fig2c, Supplementary Fig. S1); and (b) 20-23 nt smRNAs, grouped together. After CPM filtering, for the comparative analysis of D. majalis versus D. traunsteineri more peaks passed the threashold for 24 nt smRNAs (315,838) than for 20–23 nt smRNAs (102,222) (Supplementary Table S4). However, the DT analysis using a generalised linear model uncovered the opposite trend: 3,242 DT peaks were identified for the 20–23 nt smRNAs, compared to only 103 DT peaks for the 24 nt smRNAs (Supplementary Table S4, Fig. 3d–e) suggesting a consistent targeting of TEs with het-siRNAs among the allopolyploids. Very few TE-associated peaks were DT between the allotetraploids in both smRNA size classes simultaneously (Supplementary Fig. S6). In both datasets, approximately half of the DT peaks overlapped annotated TEs (Supplementary Table S4). Many of these were also located within gene introns, while a smaller number were found in the vicinity of gene promoters (Supplementary Table S4).

Similar to the results for the genic regions, D. majalis exhibited more frequent over-targeting of TEs than D. traunsteineri among DT peaks, with the exception of 20–23 nt peaks associated with TEs located around promoters, where D. traunsteineri showed increased targeting (Supplementary Table S4). The majority of TE-associated DT peaks were located within LTR retrotransposons, particularly those classified as Ty3-gypsy (Supplementary Fig. S7–S8). Among smRNAs targeting Ty3-gypsy elements, a slightly higher number targeted non-chromoviruses than chromoviruses; however, most such elements were annotated only generally as Ty3-gypsy in the D. incarnata reference genome (Supplementary Fig. S8).

We also compared smRNA targeting of TEs in the allotetraploid genomes against their parental diploids, again investigating 20–23 nt and 24 nt smRNAs separately. After CPM filtering, we retained 139,736 and 370,440 peaks for 20–23 nt and 24 nt smRNAs, respectively (Supplementary Table S4). As with genic targets, we classified the DT peaks into four categories of genomic interaction: additive, transgressive, and dominant towards either diploid. In both datasets, a significant number of shared DT peaks were found between D. majalis and D. traunsteineri across interaction categories (p < 0.001, hypergeometric test; Fig 3e-f, Supplementary Fig. S3, Fig. 4e–f, Supplementary Fig. S9–S10).

Patterns of dominance were again prevalent, with more peaks dominant towards either diploid than additive or transgressive. For 20–23 nt smRNAs, slightly more peaks showed dominance toward the diploid with lower smRNA targeting, whereas for 24 nt smRNAs the opposite trend was observed (Fig. 3e–f, Supplementary Fig. S3). The contrast between dominant types (higher vs. lower targeting) was less pronounced for 20–23 nt and more distinct for 24 nt smRNAs (Fig. 3e–f, Supplementary Fig. S3). Three patterns observed for gene targeting were also evident in TE targeting: First, for most additive peaks, the smaller genome of D. fuchsii exhibited higher smRNA targeting than the larger D. incarnata (Fig. 3e–f, Supplementary Fig. S3). Second, for transgressive peaks, both allotetraploids generally showed elevated smRNA targeting compared to the diploids (Fig. 3e–f, Supplementary Fig. S3, Supplementary Fig. S9–S10). Last, D. traunsteineri displayed greater differences to the parental diploids than D. majalis (Fig. 3e–f, Supplementary Fig. S3, Supplementary Fig. S9–S10).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the contribution of smRNAs to genomic and transcriptomic diversification following repeated allopolyploidization in Dactylorhiza majalis s.l. We examined smRNA expression in two established sibling allotetraploids and their diploid progenitors, all grown under common garden conditions, thereby minimizing environmental variation. Our primary objectives were to comparatively characterize (i) patterns of genomic interaction in the allopolyploids and (ii) smRNA-mediated regulation of TEs and gene activity.

sec.title: Consistent dominance in the allopolyploids towards the paternal and larger genome
sec.p: Allopolyploidization merges divergent genomes, giving rise to novel genetic and regulatory interactions. Common outcomes include epistasis and non-additive genetic or epigenetic effects, such as smRNA-mediated gene regulation and TE silencing. Our results reveal a consistent dominance of smRNA targeting aligned to the paternal, larger subgenome (D. incarnata), especially for 24 nt TE-associated smRNAs. This pattern was observed across both sibling allotetraploids (Fig. 4, Supplementary Fig. S5), resulting in a comparatively small number of DT peaks between them. Similar non-additive smRNA responses following hybridization and/or whole-genome duplication have been documented in Arabidopsis (Ha et al. 2009), Brassica (Fu et al. 2016; Martinez Palacios et al. 2019), and Spartina (Cavé-Radet et al. 2020), though it has remained unclear before whether such patterns remain consistent across evolutionary timescales.

Given that D. incarnata has a larger genome and higher TE load than D. fuchsii (Eriksson et al. 2022), our findings align well with previous reports that smRNA-mediated silencing often preferentially targets the TE-rich subgenome, as observed in wheat (Woodhouse et al. 2014) and Brassica rapa (Cheng et al. 2016). In stark contrast, gene expression dominance in allopolyploids frequently shifts toward the subgenome with fewer TEs, a pattern that can arise rapidly after allopolyploidization (for example in Mimulus; Edger et al. 2017) and persist across multiple generations (Gaebelein et al. 2019; Liu and Wang 2023).

While our data indicate a stronger dominance towards D. incarnata, we acknowledge that some of these patterns may be influenced by reference genome bias, as we only had access to a D. incarnata reference genome, limiting our ability to assess homeolog-specific targeting. Due to the short lengths of smRNAs and their targeting with mismatches in plants, even if references for both genomes would be available, studying subgenome effects at the level of smRNAs targeting remains a challenge. Nonetheless, in this study mapping success was comparable across samples (ca. 83%; Supplementary Table S3), and intergenic smRNA dominance towards D. fuchsii was also observed, suggesting that reference bias alone cannot account for our observations. Still, lineage-specific degradation or divergence of TEs in D. fuchsii may have reduced smRNA detection from this genome. Notably, D. incarnata and D. fuchsii diverged approximately 5.5 million years ago (Brandrud et al. 2020).

sec.title: Divergent regulation of TEs by 24 nt and 20-23 nt smRNAs
sec.p: As expected, 24 nt smRNAs—typically het-siRNAs—were strongly associated with TEs, particularly LTR retrotransposons (Fig. 2c, Supplementary Fig. S1). However, the number of DT peaks for 24 nt smRNAs between the allotetraploids was surprisingly low, suggesting that TE silencing proceeds in a relatively consistent manner across independently evolved lineages. In contrast, 20–23 nt smRNAs exhibited markedly greater divergence between the sibling allopolyploids (Fig. 3d–e), consistent with a more dynamic, lineage-specific regulatory role.

Previous studies have shown that TE-associated smRNA activity often peaks shortly after hybridization or whole-genome duplication, followed by stabilization through methylation or other epigenetic mechanisms over the next generations (Jiao et al. 2018; Martinez Palacios et al. 2019). In Arabidopsis, Ha et al. (2009) suggested that allopolyploids take advantage of smRNAs inherited from the parents to buffer initial genomic shock and promote rapid genome stabilization. The relatively lower divergence in 24 nt smRNA targeting observed in our study may reflect the advanced age of these natural allotetraploids—approximately 74k (D. traunsteineri) and 104k generations (D. majalis) (Hawranek 2021). Nonetheless, for the few DT peaks detected, smRNAs abundance was higher in the older D. majalis (Fig. 3), possibly reflecting continued regulatory refinement associated with its broader ecological range or more advanced genome diploidization.

Intriguingly, most smRNA differences associated with TE regulation in the ecologically divergent allotetraploids involved 20–23 nt smRNAs, which likely include miRNAs and nat-siRNAs. These classes are frequently implicated in responses to biotic and abiotic stress (Ito et al. 2011; Marí-Ordóñez et al. 2013; Creasey et al. 2014; Lee et al. 2020). Elevated expression of miRNAs (typically 20–22 nt long) has also been observed in resynthesized allopolyploids relative to their diploid progenitors in several systems, including Arabidopsis, Brassica, and others (Ha et al. 2009; Kenan-Eichler et al. 2011; Ghani et al. 2014), underscoring the potential role of shorter smRNAs in stress adaptation and dynamic gene regulation in polyploids.

Despite Ty1-copia being the most abundant LTR-TE in the Dactylorhiza genomes (Eriksson et al. 2022), we found more 20–23 nt smRNAs mapping to, and possibly being derived from, Ty3-gypsy elements (Supplementary Figs. S6–S7), particularly to non-chromovirus subgroups. Notably, Ty3-gypsy elements displayed contrasting patterns between the diploid progenitors: chromovirus subgroups were more prevalent in D. fuchsii, while non-chromoviruses were more common in D. incarnata (Eriksson et al. 2022). The elevated targeting of Ty3-gypsy elements by shorter smRNAs in the allopolyploids may reflect subgenome conflict or TE activation following hybridization. A similar phenomenon has been described in Gossypium, where TEs originally present in the higher-TE A-subgenome transposed into the D-subgenome post-allopolyploidization (Chen et al. 2020), suggesting that inter-subgenomic TE movement may contribute to regulatory instability and diversification.

sec.title: Genic smRNA targeting and regulatory implications
sec.p: Among others, polyploid formation causes meiotic/mitotic challanges and genetic redundancy. On one hand, even if allopolyploids have two full sets of divergent genomes, some chromosomes or chromosomal regions may still retain homology; hence it becomes crucial to sort homologous and homeologous to ensure correct chromosome segregation during meiosis. Preferential pairing of homologs has been observed in early stages of polyploid formation in Arabidopsis suecica (Pecinka et al. 2011) and Brassica napus (Grandont et al. 2014), although elevated rates of homeolog related errors have also been observed in the latter system (Xiong et al. 2021). On the other hand, given their multiple sets of gene copies, allopolyploids must enforce genetic diploidization by suppressing redundant or misregulated genes (Lee and Chen 2001; Kashkush et al. 2002; Koh et al. 2010).

Duplicated copies of some genes may be retained functional if they confer adaptive benefits, become specialised in different tissues or developmental stage through subfunctionalization, or acquire a new function through neofunctionalization (Adams et al. 2003; Blanc and Wolfe 2004; Duarte et al. 2006; De Smet et al. 2013).

In addition to silencing TEs, smRNAs—particularly 21–22 nt species—also regulate gene expression via PTGS or TGS (Borges and Martienssen 2015). We observed widespread smRNA targeting of genic regions, especially exons and 1 kb upstream of gene models (putative promoters), with 21 nt smRNAs contributing the most. While such targeting may mediate transcript degradation, alternative splicing, or cis-silencing (Guleria et al. 2011; Moss 2001), it can also represent regulatory adjustments following genome duplication, as initial steps during the diploidization process.

Strikingly, substantial genic smRNA targeting was also detected in the diploids, especially D. fuchsii. This may reflect stress-induced smRNA responses in the common garden experiment, which was conducted outdoors in Vienna, Austria—a general area where only D. incarnata occurs naturally. Environmental mismatch may have triggered stress responses in D. fuchsii, activating miRNA- and nat-siRNA-mediated regulation. Stress-induced upregulation of these types of smRNAs has been widely reported (Zhang et al. 2012; Mao et al. 2021), and recent reviews (e.g., Tiwari and Rajam 2022) highlight their role in coping with drought, salt, nutrient, and temperature stress across many plant systems.

Transgressive smRNA expression compared to diploid progenitors could offer ways in which allopolyploids respond on one side to their duplicated state, and on the other side, achieve novel ecological features, helping them to establish in niches outside of parental range. We observed more transgressive activity at peaks targeted by 20–23 nt smRNAs—compared to 24 nt—especially when the allotetraploids showed stronger regulation compared to both diploid parental species (Fig. 4e–f).

Transgressively smRNAs targeted genes were often enriched for functions related to mitosis, meiosis, gene regulation, stress responses, and transport (Fig. 5). While these categories were largely shared across the two allotetraploids, the individual genes and pathways involved differed, suggesting divergent evolutionary routes. In the younger D. traunsteineri, enrichment of smRNA targeting was observed for genes involved in cell cycle and meiotic processes, possibly reflecting ongoing resolution of meiotic instability. By contrast, the older D. majalis showed enrichments for genes involved in transcriptional and translational regulation, likely reflecting a later phase of polyploid evolution focused on dosage control and gene expression fine-tuning.

Together, these observations support a two-phase model of smRNA-mediated regulatory evolution following allopolyploidization: an early phase dominated by stabilization of chromosome behavior during meiosis, and a later phase involving refinement of gene redundancy and functional divergence. Such dynamics have been proposed in other systems including Arabidopsis, Brassica, and Gossypium (Ha et al. 2009; Fu et al. 2016; Chen et al. 2020). In Dactylorhiza we observe (i) more differences relative to diploid parents for D. traunsteineri, consistent with an earlier stage of regulatory resolution, and (ii) a higher number of upregulated smRNA peaks in D. majalis, suggesting more established and efficient regulatory networks.

sec.title: Conclusions and Future Directions
sec.p: This study underscores the dual role of small RNAs (smRNAs) in allopolyploid genome evolution—both in the stabilization of the genome via transposable element (TE) silencing and in the regulation of gene expression. Despite their shared ancestry, D. majalis and D. traunsteineri exhibit clear lineage-specific patterns of smRNA activity, particularly in genic regions, suggesting divergent regulatory trajectories following allopolyploidization.

Due to their rapid action, diversity, and regulatory plasticity, smRNAs are likely central players in the early and long-term genomic reorganization of allopolyploid species. Our results support a model in which smRNAs mediate both immediate stabilization and longer-term functional divergence after genome merging.

Future work should integrate smRNA expression profiles with homeolog-specific reference genomes and DNA methylation landscapes. Such approaches would provide deeper insights into subgenome-specific regulation, the dynamics of smRNA–target interactions, and the evolutionary consequences of smRNA-mediated gene and TE control in natural allopolyploids.
